article.title: Genetic and tissue level muscle-bone interactions during unloading and reambulation
article.abstract: Little is known about interactions between muscle and bone during the removal and application of mechanical signals.

sections.introduction: The concept of a muscle-bone unit tuned to the magnitude of contractile forces has intuitive appeal as reflected by Darcy Thompson in 1917.
sections.methods: The study design has been described previously and data for trabecular bone have been reported.
sections.results: During 3wk of unloading, muscle area (Mu.Ar) declined (p<0.001) on average by 9% (min: -26%, max: 9%)
sections.discussion: We tested for co-regulation between changes in muscle and bone during removal and reapplication of weightbearing activities

article.insights_summary: The study found that muscle and bone responses to unloading and reambulation were not correlated, suggesting that the premise of a muscle-bone unit that co-regulates its size during mechanical challenges may need to be reassessed.
article.acknowledgments: Expert technical help from Svetlana Lublinsky for the ÂµCT analysis was greatly appreciated.
